author: Candice Prosser
title: Former childcare director jailed for sex abuse of 6yo girl

organizations.name: department for education and child development

text:
Map: Adelaide 5000 
A man described as an evil and insidious sex offender has been jailed for the sexual abuse of a six-year-old girl in South Australia. 
Brenton Kelly Dickson, 36, was alleged to have molested 10 girls while working at an out-of-school-hours childcare program, but was acquitted of most of the charges. 
He was found guilty of a charge of persistent sexual exploitation of a child and jailed for five years. 
Judge Michael Boylan said Dickson, as a care worker, had abused a position of trust. 
"I readily accept the prosecution submission that your offending was insidious," he said. 
Dickson was told by the judge the victim impact statement tendered to the court "highlighted the evil of your behaviour". 
"You exploited your position of trust most cruelly," he said. "You have shown no contrition or remorse — you maintain your innocence. 
"In those circumstances you can have no insight into your offending and I cannot be confident that you are a good candidate for rehabilitation." 'Our children need to be kept safe' 
Judge Boylan told Dickson his offending had cast a shadow over male teachers and carers, and had affected parents and children. 
"Your conduct has ... affected male carers and teachers ... caring, hard-working men in such positions may feel they work under a cloud of suspicion and must always be on their guard," he said. 
"Offending such as yours may cause honourable men to no longer work with children — that is a serious disadvantage to our community." 
Judge Boylan said Dickson had ruined the young girl's life. 
"Our children need to be kept safe," he said. 
He sentenced Dickson to five years in jail with a non-parole term of three years. Mother now wary of out-of-school care 
One of the mothers whose child was involved in the case said outside court she was pleased Dickson had been jailed, but was upset at handling of the matter by the school involved and the education department. 
"How was this man allowed to be the only carer on site at any one time?" she said. 
She said she would never again put her children in an out-of-school-hours care program. 
"Myself, as a mother, trusted Brenton for six years — not only was he grooming children at the school, he was grooming mothers like me," she said. 
In a statement, a spokesman for the Department for Education and Child Development said the "school community was notified by letter of the initial allegations and again at each appropriate point of the legal proceedings". 
"This included a letter when charges were laid, when court proceedings commenced and when the conviction was recorded," the statement said. 
"All victims were referred to the Child Protection Service which is the lead agency in relation to supporting victims of child abuse."
